Award.AwardTitle: Balloon Observations of Gamma-ray Glows from Thunderstorms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Thunderstorms are high-energy environments consisting of electric fields and radiation sources. Gamma-ray emissions from thunderstorms are known as gamma-ray glows and are often terminated by lightning. However, there have been few observations of gamma-ray glows, and little is known about how and where they are created and how they may relate to the initiation of lightning. This project will combine new observations and computer modeling to better understand this phenomena. The main aspect of the project will be the deployment of gamma-ray sensors on balloons that will be flown into thunderstorms to collect data. A potential impact of the project is through the improved understanding of lightning initiation, which may eventually lead to better warnings and lightning safety. Multiple students would be involved in the project, thereby training the next generation of scientists.

The research team will conduct balloon-based observations of gamma-ray glows. The work will improve upon a prior design of a balloon-borne instrument that detects gamma-ray glows using Geiger counters by incorporating an inorganic scintillator and a slow electric field measurement. Thirty flights are planned over the course of the proposal period from central Florida. The data, along with Monte Carlo simulations of gamma-ray propagation, would be used to: 1) Determine the frequency of gamma-ray glows and their relationship to thunderstorm meteorology and lightning, 2) Determine source mechanism(s) for gamma-ray glows, 3) Determine discharge currents produced by gamma-ray glows in the source regions, 4) Constrain electric fields present in glow source regions/lightning initiation regions and determine durations of high fields occurring before lightning, 5) Determine relationship between glows, lightning and TGFs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to develop and construct small, inexpensive balloon payloads to measure gamma-ray glows produced by thunderstorms. Gamma-ray glows are MeV emissions from thunderstorms that usually last from seconds to minutes. They are often terminated by lightning, illustrating a possible connection between the gamma-ray source region and lightning initiation. Prior to this project, there have been few dedicated observations of the glows, and so the goal is to launch a large number of balloons payloads into thunderstorms to record properties of the gamma-ray glows. Central Florida is the thunderstorm capital of the United States, making it an excellent location for the balloon campaigns. However, the proximity of the ocean and the swampy terrain increase the odds that a given payload might not be recovered. Therefore, the approach is to use a large number of inexpensive payloads, which may or may not be recovered. This approach has the advantage that the large number of flights can be used to determine statistical properties of the gamma?ray glows such as how frequent they are and under what conditions they are found to occur.

A total of 15 launches were performed over the course of the three summers. Most were recovered with the exception of a few that landed far out into the Atlantic Ocean. In total, ten payloads were constructed with the final design and 5 of them were released during 2019 thunderstorm season from Melbourne, FL. 4 out of 5 launches were successfully done with payload being recovered containing data. No gamma-ray glows were detected during these flights despite flight paths that were in or near thunderstorms. Earlier flights, which have been analyzed as part of this project, showed that gamma-ray glows are common. However, the later flights detected no gamma-ray glows. Further flights are needed to determine if the difference is a statistical fluctuation or due to different thunderstorm environments.
